STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 7, 2022
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 7, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(a) Verification of education
One of twelve personnel files reviewed did not contain documentation of education
requirement was obtained prior to employment as required.
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of twelve personnel files reviewed did not contain documentation that out of state
central registry clearance was completed prior to employment as required.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training
4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training in
and maintain a current certification in first aid from the America
Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other institution
approved by the department.
Two of eight open foster home files reviewed did not have verification of current first
aid certification as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
4

One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have the reevaluation completed at
least 15 days prior to the expiration date of the foster home license as required.
File one: License expired on 1/5/2022 and the reevaluation was completed on
12/22/2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three open independent living files reviewed did not contain verification the
independent living contract was completed and shared with the youth every 90 days
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
6/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/21/2020
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MSA violation. Please note that there
are additional MSA requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional MSA requirements except for the following:
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in
foster home/relative placements.
5

Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no documented FTM for 1/6/2022 placement change.
File two: There is no documented FTM for 12/13/2021 placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
6/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/21/2020
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021 (cited under FOM 722-09)
6/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/21/2020
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
6

Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the PATP.
Two of three independent living files reviewed did not contain all of the required
signatures on the PATP.
File one: 10/11/2021 PATP was not uploaded so unable to verify signatures;
12/10/2021 & 3/2/2022 PATP do not have foster parent and youth signatures.
File two: Relative caregiver signature was not obtained timely for 12/20/2021 PATP
(1/31/2022) and mother's signature was missing.
File three: PATP verifying youth's signature was not uploaded for 7/23/2021 USP,
1/6/2022 USP or 3/31/2022 USP.
File four: Signature for youth on 11/23/2021 PATP was not obtained timely
(1/25/2022).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
6/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/21/2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency should upload the closing letter for special investigations sent to
foster parents.
 Help desk tickets should be uploaded into MiSACWIS if it impacts meeting
licensing or policy expectations.
 All signed documents should include dates of signatures.
 If a candidate has graduated but not yet received diploma or official
transcripts obtain a letter from the college or university that verifies candidate
has completed requirements.
 Update new hire checklist to include inquiry regarding living outside of
Michigan within in the past 5 years.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2022C0112002 was initiated on 11/19/2021 due to allegations the agency was
not responsive to after hours crisis or emergencies. The investigation determined
violations of R 400.12202 policies and procedures. A CAP was approved on
1/19/2022 and continues to be implemented at this time.
7

The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 5/28/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
6/30/2021. During the review the agency had ten violations. Seven citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall
compliance. In addition, the agency noted that staff turnover and retention impacted
overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the previous
year CAP was effective due processes being put in place that the agency feels has
reduced the number of citations. The Chief Administrator assessment reported
ongoing challenges related to COVID-19 have impacted overall compliance with
licensing rules and policy. Due to various restrictions put in place some contacts and
case requirements were not able to occur due to staff or clients experiencing
symptoms of illness. In addition, staff turnover has been a large barrier.
The Chief Administrator indicated ongoing training and support for staff and
supervisors has been a focus of the agency. Additional oversight, development of
CAP driven inter-office policies and procedures, and implementation of checklists
have had a positive impact. The Chief Administrator expressed confidence that
several areas will improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged there
were some challenges related to adjusting to hybrid schedules but overall felt as
though the agency has adjusted well to changes related to COVID-19. Staff reported
it would be helpful if the mileage reimbursed could be increased due to the rising gas
prices. Staff reported feeling supported by supervisors and co-workers and reported
no areas of need.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
8

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
____________6/7/2022________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 7, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica Vandenheuvel Date
Area Manager
9
